Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 03:14PM - edited Jun 21, 2011 03:14PM by kll22 I am officially part of the ddTC clinicial trial and very anxious to start.  I hate the waiting and anticipation but am very grateful to all of you for sharing your experiences.  I talked to a chemo nurse on Monday and she was fantastic; answered all of my questions and gave me some tips (drink ice water during treatment to reduce mouth sores) plus she shared a shortcut to the chemo treatment area (right now, it's all about the little details!) One more day until steroids...
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 07:31AM kll22 wrote: Merilee - for me "dose dense" means that I am having TC every two weeks for 4 cycles rather than every three weeks.  I'm participating in a clinical trial looking at how well tolerated TC is at the faster rate and it includes a regular Neulasta injection to maintain higher levels of white blood cells during treatment.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 12:35PM kll22 wrote: Mrs. Mott - glad to help!  We're supposed to flush the chemo drugs out of our systems as quickly as possible so my MO recommends 3 quarts of water per day for a few days post infusion.  Water tastes horrible to me after treatment so I've been trying lots of other beverages -- tea, smoothies, juice and soda combos and, my new favorite, Carnation Instant Breakfast mix with milk.  Today  (day four) is my "Why me" day, when I'm at my lowest -- cranky, sad, achy and sore -- although not as bad as last time.  It doesn't help that my hair is coming out by the handful.  I can't quite make up my mind to get rid of it all.  I don't think I'm ready yet.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 03:59PM kll22 wrote: Pity party at my house tonight!  #3 is wiping me out.  I'm sure it's a combination of me being extra tired (love that cumulative effect!), feeling guilty about not being at work (I'm in fundraising and now is our busiest time of the year with eight events over the next two months--gotta love it when work calls AFTER you email that you are not functioning well, ugh), and starting to feel nervous and emotional about finishing chemo (how hard will #4 be; what if the cancer comes back).  What will the new normal be? THANK YOU to all you wonderful women going through this for allowing me to vent!  Better now. Maryanne - no experience with any gels, etc.  I chose not to shave my head when my hair started falling out; that was just too much for me to face and I like that I have a little hair showing under the hats I wear.  My eyebrows and eyelashes thinned but I still have both and am filling in with Bobbie Brown espresso shadow.  Chemo is entirely do-able. SEs are managable and if they are giving you trouble, call your doc.  There is no need to suffer!  I was terrified at the start but feel very empowered to be fighting back - with the occaisional rant as needed.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2011 12:54PM kll22 wrote: Hope everyone is having a wonderful weekend!  I finally feel like I have a bit more energy, which is good because we are celebrating my son's b-day tomorrow and I need to bake a cake.  A really odd SE to report:  Both of my cheeks below my eyes, have round, red circles on them.  It looks like I'm blushing in an odd place and seems to just be dry skin patches. VLNRPH - which orchestra are you with?  My daughter is giving up the viola this year and it made me very sad.  Fortunately, my son is keeping up with it.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 01:54PM kll22 wrote: Is anyone else feeling overly emotional as they face their final chemo?  I have had crying jags on and off for the past three days and I'm afraid I'm going to be an emotional wreck tomorrow when I meet with my MO.  As best as I can figure, I'm : -scared of being done and the possibility of recurrence even though I firmly believe there is no cancer left in me and there hasn't been since surgery. -feeling relieved to almost be done with the step that was a huge hurdle for me emotionally.  I remember crying with relief after surgery and these feelings seem to be similar. -worried that #4 will be the hardest because I am already so wiped.  I am very grateful for the four weeks to recover before rads.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 05:22PM kll22 wrote: Thank you, everyone!  I appreciate the insights and support.  I spent alot of time this afternoon just being, feeling the emotions and addressing them.  And then I had an "ah ha" moment. My emotions also could be related to normal monthly hormones -- no chemo-pause for me. All in all I am feeling a bit better and more in control.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2011 06:47PM - edited Aug 8, 2011 03:52PM by kll22 Chickadee - my first thought was how quickly we are consumed by living with a cancer diagnosis and forget about all those other "normal" aspects to life.  I think yesterday was a welcome introduction back to "normal" for me. Another long day in the chair although I actually fell asleep through my Cytoxan!  I got a lovely card from my doc and nurses congratulatng me on finishing today.  It brought tears to my eyes.  They are truly special people and I am grateful for the role they played in my life.  Now I'm tired and have an upset tummy.  First meeting with rad onc on the 22nd.  Onward!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 08:29AM kll22 wrote: Congratulations, Chickadee!  What a milestone!  Hope everything goes well today and over the next few days with mild SEs.  Enjoy getting back to normal for a while! Mrs. Mot- my MO gave the okay for me to use the Lorazepam he prescribed for nasuea as a sleep aid.  I sometimes have touble shutting down at night -- that's my normal time to worry and think too much. I take it on an as needed basis, maybe once or twice a week, and it's made a world of difference.  Just something to consider.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 11:41AM kll22 wrote: I think Jeanne finishes today.  Congratulations!! 4th hit me hard, too.  More finger pain (couldn't ice due to a syndrome I'm "blessed" with); much more tired and I feel like I'm walking around with 40 lb weights attached to my legs.  I talked to the MOs office yesterday who told me that in terms of excercise & stamina, chemo makes you feel like you haven't done anything for a year.  That pretty much sums it up!  Finally feeling a step closer to normal two weeks out. Stay strong everyone!

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2011 05:10PM kll22 wrote: Welcome,  Maryanne. Nothing scary to report from my experience with TC.  Like you, I was terrified before my first because I didn't know what to expect and how I would react. Once the first one is done, you will know what to expect.  Track your SEs day by day and you'll know how to prep next time.  Follow your MOs instructions on fluid intake, and if things get too bad call and ask for advice.  Days 3 - 5 were the worst for me but certainly managable.  My son commented the other day that chemo hasn't been as bad as he expected and I agreed.  Above all, give yourself permission to rest.  It is exhausting and that increases over time.  You can do this! VLNRPH - yes, I do wear glasses. I've been slathering on moisturizer with sunscreen like normal and using California Baby aloe vera lotion for sensitive skin, which helps. REVMAMA- I'd add make sure you're eating a good amount of protein and getting your fluids.  Most importantly, go with the flow; if you need rest then rest.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 05:05PM kll22 wrote: Wooo Hooo MrsMot!  Congrats on finishing chemo!  You can put that all behind you soon! Hope your post chemo goes smoothly this week.  For me, rads were easier than chemo.  I started four weeks after chemo and finished last week (28 plus 5 boosts).  The hardest part is going every weekday. My skin got very red and irritated in places but I never blistered.  Use lots of lotion - whatever your RO recommends.  I had great luck with Aquaphor and a 99% aloe vera I found at Trader Joes. I also tried to drink lots of water to stay hydrated and eat lots of protein to help with healing.  You'll do great! VLNRPH-so sorry to hear that the lymphedema continues to be a problem. Wish I had some advice to share!

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 06:25AM - edited Jul 11, 2011 12:26PM by kll22 Round two complete and am now officially halfway through chemo!  What a great feeling.  Neulasta today and then comes the bone pain but I'm hoping to stay on top of it this time.  I even made it a night out with family last night!  Next challenge is downing all those fluids, Ughh. I don't know how many of you will agree but I'm sure quite a few will - the idea of chemo is generally worse than the actual procedure and SEs.  I think we've been frightened by how cancer and its treatment is portrayed on TV as well as how it plays out in our imaginations.  It is a life changing event -- my new normal for the time being as I like to think of it.  We will get through this and be stronger in the long run! Have a wonderful weekend everyone!

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 04:58PM kll22 wrote: Hi Ladies - first time posting here.  I am 2 1/2 weeks PFC and seeing some very fine, sporadic growth, which makes me very excited.  I did not shave my head because I liked having a little hair showing when I wear my hats.  I finally made friends with my wig after having my stylist trim the bangs so they weren't so heavy.  She raved about how close the wig was to my actual hair which made me feel much better. I still feel fake wearing it but I get tired of  looking around the bills of caps all the time.  So many different solutions to this one problem!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 10:06AM - edited Oct 21, 2011 10:06AM by kll22 Hi Ladies - I've been lurking for a while and wanted to chime in.  I am now 11 weeks PFC (boy does that go fast!) and have been going topless since 9 weeks. I hit a point where the hats were bothering me - I hated the limited vision I had with the brims - and I didn't feel like me with the wig.  I had between 1/4 and 1/2 inch and good coverage when I called it quits.  I love it and everyone says how great I look with the super short hair.  I have to admit that if anyone asks why I "cut" my hair so short, I'm tempted to whisper "head lice" and see what the reaction is!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2011 08:45AM kll22 wrote: Thank you so much to all of you for posting pics and sharing your stories. I am 5 weeks PFC today (Yay!) and am starting to see sprouts.  It is encouragingl to see how beautiful everyone looks as they return to "normal".

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 05:09PM kll22 wrote: Thank you ladies for posting!  I am 5 days PFC and am looking forward to a bright and long future!  I especially appreciate your post, MAYWIN.  As a fellow TN, I intend to follow in your footsteps!
Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2012 01:19PM kll22 wrote: I have my next visit with my MO in August (yay 1 year!!) and I'll bring it up then. I wanted to use ice but MO said no because I have Reynauld's syndrome which makes my fingers turn white and cold like the circulation has stopped.  I too had the ridges on my nails and didn't lose any until Christmas. That started a succession of nail losses on my toes. I'm also experiencing joint pain but mainly in my knees. BC is just one great big roller coaster, isn't it?!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan Effects on Nails kll22 Denise-G

Posts.Content: kll22 wrote: I'm curious about what others have experienced in terms of nail loss after chemo. I finished 4ddTC 10 months ago. After chemo, most of my finger and toe nails were affected in some fashion but are now normal except for two - my thumb nail and big toe nail on my left side - the side I received my infusions on. I am in the process of losing the thumb nail for the third time and the toe nail for the second time. Has anyone had a similar experience? 4 ddTC; 28 rads + 5 boosts Dx 5/6/2011, IDC, Right, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan Effects on Nails kll22 Denise-G
